thread.title: Poll: Trump leads Cruz 21-16 in Texas
thread.title_full: Poll: Trump leads Cruz 21-16 in Texas

title: Poll: Trump leads Cruz 21-16 in Texas
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Poll: Trump leads Cruz 21-16 in Texas Donald Trump leads the Republican field by five points over his nearest competition in Texas, according to a new Lyceum poll of Texas. Post to Facebook Poll: Trump leads Cruz 21-16 in Texas Donald Trump leads the Republican field by five points over his nearest competition in Texas, according to a new Lyceum poll of Texas.  //kvue.tv/1KOW7oD   Poll: Trump leads Cruz 21-16 in Texas KVUE 11:09 a.m. CDT October 1, 2015 Donald Trump arrives for jury duty at New York Supreme Court August 17, 2015 in New York. (Photo: DON EMMERT/AFP/Getty Image) CONNECT TWEET   
AUSTIN -- Businessman Donald Trump leads the Republican field by five points over his nearest competition in Texas, according to a new Lyceum poll of the Lone Star State. 
According to the poll , Trump captures 21 percent of the GOP field among registered voters planning to vote in the Texas Republican Primary followed by Senator Ted Cruz at 16 percent, Dr. Ben Carson at 12 percent, and former Florida Governor Jeb Bush at 10 percent. All other candidates in the GOP field were in single digits with former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina pulling in six percent of the vote. 
Trump garnered support from a wide range of the electorate, leading with voters 65 and older and those 45-64 along with voters under 29. He trailed Carson among voters 30 to 44 years old by just one percent and was just three percent behind Senator Ted Cruz among fundamentalist voters. 
According to the Texas Lyceum poll , if Trump left the race before the Texas primary in March 2016, more than a third of his voters would gravitate to Senator Cruz while 24 percent would move over to Carson. The remaining voters supporting Trump would be split up among the other candidates. 
On the Democratic side, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton leads the field with 36 percent of the vote followed by Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders at 24 percent, Vice-President Joe Biden at 15 percent (he hasn't declared a candidacy yet), and former Virginia Senator Jim Webb at two percent. 
The poll found Clinton leads among African-American and Hispanic voters, but trails Sanders among white voters by five percent. Clinton also has a 23 point lead over Sanders among female voters, but loses male voters by one percent to Sanders, 29 to 28 percent. 
In hypothetical general election races in Texas, Clinton trails Bush 27 to 35 percent, but 39 percent are undecided. Cruz leads Clinton by seven percent with 29 percent undecided. When it comes to Trump, Clinton is just two percent behind the Republican frontrunner in Texas 37 to 39 percent with a quarter of the electorate undecided, according to the poll. 
As for President Barack Obama, 52 percent of Texans said he is doing either a very good or somewhat good job as president compared to 44 percent who said he is either doing a somewhat poor or very poor job. Obama has positive job ratings among Democrats, Independents, African-Americans, Hispanics, voters 18-29, voters 30-44, but is in negative numbers when it comes to Republicans, white voters, and voters over the age of 45.  //kvue.tv/1KOW7oD TOP VIDEOS
